Has anyone elseâ€™s received the email today from our AD::: Todd Stansbury. It basically reiterated his disappointment in our season but that under Geoff Collins our recruiting has improved to a top 25 class for two years and he is going to continue to support him and give him time.

Here was my direct response that I sent him;

Mr. Stansbury:::

With all due respect::: I will never call Geoff Collins a coach. He is at best a hype man. He does not exhibit leadership::: discipline or any respect for the traditions that has made Tech great. He takes no personal responsibility for our play and we continue to be one of the most penalized teams in the league::: including repeated unsportsmanlike
penalties. That starts from the top. Remember Mr. Collins refusal to shake Pittsburgâ€™s head coachâ€™s hand after our loss?
The losses are bad enough unto themselves::: (Citadel and Northern Illinois come to mind)::: but his lack of character has made us a laughing stock across the nation. Continuing to make the same mistakes and expecting different results is the definition of stupidity. The longer Collins remains at Tech the more harm he causes to our program::: our school and your reputation as a competent AD. Itâ€™s time to admit you made a mistake by giving this conman a seven year contract and cut our losses.

Sincerely:::
Douglas Woodall::: Alumni.

column1:
It's science friction. Inspired after watching The Avengers::: engineers at Georgia Tech wondered if Thanos could have actually snapped his fingers wearing the Infinity Gauntlet.

What they found out was that a finger snap is one of the fastest movements the human body is capable of performing. Each snap happens in 7 milliseconds â€“ twenty times faster than the blink of an eye. Your arm muscles are the motors::: tendons are the springs::: and the friction created between your finger and thumb is pivotal for making it happen. -- https://c.gatech.edu/3nmJ5cX
Falling in love all over againâ€¦ ğŸ’›ğŸ

column1: Since 1998::: there has been a Gold Fella at every Georgia Tech home football game. Grab your gold wig for A Day in the Life of The Gold Fellas.

On the eve of her first visit to campus::: she and her mother slept in the Coca-Cola building parking lot to save money. During her first year::: her father passed away from cancer.

The ultimate gift for a Georgia Tech grad? How about his very own Ramblin' Wreck.

For architecture grad John Caddell's 91st birthday::: his daughter found a Ford Model A Sport Coupe in Florida and had the car shipped to Georgia and restored to match the iconic gold beauty that has been maintained by students on campus for more than 60 years.

This replica has pennant flags that read "Give 'Em Hell Caddell!" just for John! -- https://c.gatech.edu/3aWlQzv

column1: DROP A COMMENT: Tell us something about your time at Georgia Tech that would immediately date you without actually mentioning the year.

column1:
We dug through our archives to find the only picture in existence of Georgia Tech's record 222-0 win over Cumberland College that happened on this day 105 years ago. It's still the largest margin of victory on record in college football.

Tech was coached by John Heisman and in this game never attempted a forward pass and still scored 32 touchdowns. Cumberland never completed a first down.
column3: Understand that Tech never had a first down either. Maybe just a myth.
column4: Love this! My great uncle Marshall Guill â€œ Shortyâ€ played under Coach Heisman on that team . My daughter AJ is a junior at Tech now !! ğŸ–¤ğŸ’›ğŸ–¤
column5:
I am a Tech grad and this is actually kind of embarrassing. Cumberland had shut down their football team before the season and Heisman won't let them off the hook with the game contract::: so they had to scramble to get a team together to honor the contract. Cumberland would have had to pay Tech $3k if they backed out. Heisman gave Cumberland $500 so that they can come play the game. It was payback for Heisman as Cumberland baseball team beat Tech's 22-0 the previous Spring. Conveniently::: Heisman was also Tech's baseball coach. There was nothing honorable about the contest. https://
en.wikipedia.org
/wiki/
1916_Cumberland_
vs._Georgia_Tec
h_football_game

North Avenue is one of the oldest named roads in the city of Atlanta::: and originally helped mark the northernmost city limits. When Georgia Tech was under construction::: campus was on the outskirts of town. Now::: we're right smack dab in the middle of it all.

Check out this picture we dug up from 1900. You can see North Avenue was still unpaved. And yes::: that's Tech Tower in the background.

column10:
I remember 1969::: sitting in the office of director of admissions::: Jerry Hitt's office::: with my parents when he reviewed my transcript and my SAT scores::: and said::: "i'm going to go ahead and admit you::: right now."

Ultimately::: I was accepted as a Navy ROTC scholarship student::: and graduated 14-1/2 quarters later in March of 1974. Seven others from my high school::: all men::: entered in 1969::: and a total of four of us out of the eight graduated with "engineering" on our diplomas. The other four went elsewhere along the way.

Every type of aircraft I flew in the Navy::: and every ship I served on::: is no longer in service. One of the helicopters I actually flew is on display in the National Museum of Naval Aviation in Pensacola.

So::: how do you go down in history? Just survive long enough::: and it happens.

â€¢Georgia Tech graduate Michael Arad::: who designed New York's 9/11 Memorial.
â€¢Georgia Tech alumnus and faculty member Gen. Philip Breedlove::: who was inside the Pentagon during the attack.
â€¢Aerospace Engineering lecturer Kelly Griendling::: who was a first year student in class on campus that day twenty years ago.

column1:
Kevin Lewis wrote about his father's life and legacy in his application to Georgia Tech.
Kevin was just 1 when the September 11 attacks happened just a few miles from his hometown on Long Island. His father::: Andrew::: was an NYPD officer who drove back into the city after his overnight shift and ended up working at ground zero for months helping with the search and recovery effort.

In 2017::: Andrew Lewis lost a valiant battle with 9/11-related brain cancer just a year before his son came to Tech. Kevin is now remembering his father's legacy::: a fourth-year student in civil engineering. "I want to make the world a better place for everyone else around me just like my father did. I wake up every day determined to be the son::: brother::: and citizen he was shaping me to be.â€ -- https://c.gatech.edu/September11

column1:
Not long after finishing his masterâ€™s degree in architecture at Georgia Tech::: Michael Arad witnessed the tragic events of 9/11 from the rooftop of his apartment building in Manhattan. Crediting his lessons and mentorship at Tech::: Arad designed New York Cityâ€™s 9/11 Memorial to be a space that allows people to come together and commemorate as a community. His design was chosen from thousands of submissions.

Arad was asked to design a new component for the site::: and he came up with the Memorial Glade::: a space dedicated to first responders and survivors::: workers and residents::: who still feel the effects of the disaster to this day. Thousands were exposed to airborne hazards and toxins around the World Trade Center site::: resulting in chronic illnesses and deaths. Stone monoliths inlaid with steel recovered from the destruction point skyward in the same location where the primary ramp used during the rescue and recovery effort once stood.

Now::: 20 years after the attacks::: the bronzed panels that flank the reflecting pools on all sides::: etched with 2:::983 names of the men::: women::: and children who perished in the attacks remain an integral component of the memorial experience.

â€œNo picture or video can do justice:::â€ says Arad. â€œYou have to be here to get a sense of the scale and the space to take it in.â€ -\-\ https://c.gatech.edu/September11

Georgia Tech biomedical engineering professor Cassie Mitchell won a silver medal in the F51 club throw at the Paralympics in Tokyo today::: setting a new American record.

Despite being paralyzed from the chest down::: Mitchell is not only one of the world's leading disabled athletes in throwing events â€“ but she's also a leading researcher who combines engineering and data science to forecast diseases and optimize treatments for patients with neurological injuries and disorders like herself. -- https://c.gatech.edu/38GBNZe

column3: I have a story for Shane::: and it's true. A few years ago::: when i lived in minneapolis::: I had some friends over to my downtown condo for a thing. One of the girls was really into astronomy and had all kinds of stuff about space::: including the ISS. So we walk out on the balcony::: and a flashing light in the sky is moving in an weird direction coming right over our heads. We're like "is that a plane?"::: and we arched our heads upwards as the light passed directly over my balcony. Then she says "The ISS!" and we went on the website to find its location::: and it was right over Minnesota on its way over Wisconsin. The odds of that happening on a clear night passing right over our heads are....... astronomical.

column76:
Our FUTURE continues to look amazingly gifted::: highly intelligent::: and extremely BRILLIANT!!!!

Shhhhh.....Here
is a little secret: When Georgia Tech invites alumni/alumnae to return to campus to engage with GT undergraduates.

Imagine a table of eight (8) with two GT alums and six (6) GT undergraduates.
The school asks alums to remain seated while under grads introduce themselves to us...

When we walk between the Student Center and Library we::: alums intently are listening to you.

We observe you on Ga PBS. Undergraduates competing for $25K from venture capitalist within your own firms and you havenâ€™t yet received your undergraduate degrees!!!

In the history of the USA how many 15 year old start Aerospace Engineering????
?

Back at that table of eight we::: alumni hear young folk from across the world. We listen to top graduate students. We learn your future big plans and dreams. We know that our world and FUTURE will be left within your capable hands!!!!

Donâ€™t play us cheap. Every new GT student was among the smartest and brightest student where ever they came across the globe. It is fascinating::: exciting::: and intriguing to witness OUR FUTURE before our eyes!!!!!

As tax paying citizens the faculty and administrators equally have to be among the most stellar performers to maintain their positions.

Every year the caliber of Yellow Jacket grows brighter and smarter!!!!

Some of you are pursuing degrees in technical subjects which werenâ€™t in existence when some of us matriculated at Georgia Tech like bioengineering:::
AI::: nanotechnology:::
etc.

Georgia Tech is steadily throwing red meat to academic lions and great young minds!!!!

It is arduous gaining acceptance into GT. You will learn plenty and SURVIVE your ordeal particularly with your fellow GT schoolmates!!!!
!

Congratulations
! We are exceedingly PROUD of ALL of you!!!!! #AcademicallyGif
ted #Impressive

P.S. It is among the worst kept secrets. The world already knows you have tremendous intellect!!!!!!

Finding this ice might provide water that could sustain human life during planetary travel or be used to make rocket fuel or fuel for combustion engines on-site::: rather than loading a rocket with those supplies. 25 years ago::: Georgia Tech's campus served as the heart of Olympic Village â€“ where athletes lived::: journalists reported::: and visitors from around the world gathered for the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. Tech also served as the venue for swimming::: diving::: synchronized swimming::: water polo::: modern pentathlon::: boxing::: and Paralympic volleyball.

We're sharing a few of our favorite Olympic stories and images from the Games that changed our campus and city forever. Share your memories (and photos if you've got them!) in the comments below.
column3: GT and metro ATL did an amazing job hosting the Olympics and the athletes!
column4: This was such an amazing time to be at Georgia Tech and in Atlanta::: both during the Olympics and in the time prior to Atlanta winning the bid in 1990 to host the event. I worked with a group of students::: faculty::: and staff known as the Georgia Tech Olympic Coalition (GTOC) that helped to welcome IOC delegations to campus when they came to visit Atlanta when we were competing for the bid. We did other things to raise campus awareness of Atlanta's bid for the Olympics prior to the 1990 announcement. In the period between 1990-1996::: GTOC turned its focus toward a variety of community service projects::: and those of us who were interested in volunteering for the 1996 Olympics could keep a record of volunteer activities that could be used to apply for a volunteer spot. I did that::: and I got my first pick and "dream job" choice of where I wanted to volunteer -\-\ the basketball and gymnastics venues at the Georgia Dome. While working::: I got to see much of the competition for free::: and I worked some press conferences::: including the one with Kerri Strug after the women's team captured the team gold medal (I got to see the competition where they won the gold too and saw Kerri stick that vault while injured). I also got to run disks for Associated Press photographers to their dedicated lab during the men's basketball team's game vs. China::: and got to see digital photography in its infancy::: with images being transmitted via computer to their offices in Boston. Seeing the GT campus transformed into the Olympic Village was amazing and seeing the world come together at that time is something that I will always cherish. Along with GTOC's hospitality::: Georgia Tech's technical know how helped the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games capture the bid::: with its 3D multimedia presentations::: and the solar powered roof that was installed and monitored on the aquatic center is still in operation at the Campus Recreation Center today (faculty researchers from my school monitored the rooftop system's performance at the time and they still do today). The Olympic torch was designed by Georgia Tech faculty too. There are even more GT contributions that I'm not remembering right now::: but those are just a few. Having the Olympics here was truly game-changing for both Atlanta and Georgia Tech. I will always::: always remember it. â¤
column5: At the time I was working in the Baker Building. A while before the Olympics::: we had to start parking at a lot near Atlantic Steel::: and then catch a shuttle bus. I ended up taking leave the whole time of the Olympics so that I wouldn't have to deal with the mess of getting to work. Also::: we had lots of family members coming into town to see the games.

column7: Hanging with Katie Couric in the Student Center. I designed the electric trams for transporting the athletes inside the Olympic Village and supported the electric buses in the Village.
column8: Wish I had pics but I was there in the middle of it. They built the GaState dorms (now GT) across N Ave. The center of campus was torn up and there were fences everywhere. About every building on campus was used for some Olympic purpose (housing::: meeting::: etc). Exciting times and after it was over the campus and surrounding area benefited (IMHO) tremendously!

column14: I worked for the Olympic Village Logistics Division and had a blast. Eating in the dining hall::: concerts at the night club (right next to the ISyE building)::: the video and virtual reality arcade::: so much fun. I actually wrote an article about it for IIE Solutions magazine back then.

column18: I was working in CRB and did the whole â€œpark at Atlantic Steel and ride a shuttle busâ€ grind (and then parked in whatâ€™s now the GTRI/GPB deck on 14th during the Paralympics). I was able to get a day pass and walk through campus (to get lunch at Juniorâ€™s) one day::: and it was amazing to see how completely they transformed campus (and the whole city::: really).
column19: Who's down for reviving pin trading this weekend downtown? :)
column20:
I was so fortunate to get a job that summer (the summer between my freshman and sophomore year at Tech) working in the Tech bookstore (which was right next to the Student Center). It was turned into a souvenir and sundry shop for the athletes. I got to meet a ton of athletes::: got many athlete pins::: NBC hosted their Today show every morning from the textiles building across the sidewalk (where they had removed an entire wall of that building to have a better background for the show)::: and saw several government officials from the US and other countries. Only scary experience was the day I was eating lunch outside on campus and the cops were searching trash cans for bombs the day after the Centennial Park bombing. Other than that one of the absolute coolest experiences of my life!!

I was also fortunate to see a diving competition on campus and attend the Womenâ€™s Gymnastics team final where the US won their first team gold medal (the famous Kerri Strug vault)!
column21: I was there. I lived close enough to ride my bicycle in. There was a parking lot next to the Van Leer building where I parked my bike. Not much work was done at Georgia Tech those 3 weeks.

Fast forward to 2016 and my son is at georgia tech - and he lived in those dorms (the picture is of us visiting him and me reminding him that his parents lived where the cafeteria is now and I worked in the white building LOL). column1: In a year amongst the trees::: the SlothBot battled wind::: rain::: snow::: insects::: and even lost a toe. On this day in 1994::: the Atlanta Olympic Committee broke ground on Georgia Techâ€™s campus for the Olympic Aquatic Center::: the swimming and diving venue for the 1996 games. The facility was designed by husband-and-wife duo Bill and Ivenue Stanley::: Techâ€™s first Black architecture graduates.

After the Olympics::: the facility was enclosed and repurposed to become Georgia Techâ€™s state-of-the-art Campus Recreation Center. The pool and diving well remain and have hosted countless Olympians for training and competition.
column3: Fun Fact: I swam in a mock swim meet at the Georgia Tech Aquatic Center a few weeks before the "real" Olympics began. They recruited swimmers from year-round clubs across the State of Georgia::: and I had the honor of swimming the 50 meter freestyle for "Sweden" and the 800 medley relay for "Korea". It was the most awesome experience of my life... And it solidified my desire to attend Tech â¤ It sounds weird::: but I still dream about that Olympic experience... It was so surreal to experience it.

During an Olympic swimming event I attended at that beautiful venue::: there was an incident in the stands where a man in a cap with a neck cape (one of those French Foreign Legion caps) sat by himself. The crowd in the area became agitated. It looked serious. But security arrived and::: after a moment::: escorted the man out peacefully.

Step one::: find your meditation spot. Step two::: sit in a comfortable position. Step three::: put on your virtual reality headset.

Wait... put on your virtual reality headset?

ZenVR is a virtual reality program that gives users the tools to learn meditation::: increase mindfulness::: and help decrease stress and anxiety in their everyday lives. Starting out as a research project as part of his human-computer interaction master's degree::: ZenVR creator Matthew Golino was so encouraged by the mental health results of his participants in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic that he entered Georgia Tech's CREATE-X accelerator to turn his project into product. | https://c.gatech.edu/ZenVR

Georgia Tech researchers have seen dramatic results using flickering lights and sound waves to treat Alzheimerâ€™s disease. This noninvasive treatment uses an experimental visor to kick-start the brainâ€™s immune response to clear disease-causing pathogens. Itâ€™s the next step in finding a cure for Alzheimerâ€™s. -- https://c.gatech.edu/3h69qYn

Pollinators::: like bees::: are essential to our ecosystem. The Georgia Tech Urban Honey Bee Project has been tagging bees with RFID chips to learn more about their mating behavior in urban areas.

column1: Aya Ayoubi's experiences studying abroad while at Georgia Tech expanded her perspective as a designer. The refugee crisis in her native country of Jordan inspired the design of Delta Jacket â€” winner of the InVenture Prize competition. #RamblinOn #GT21

Isabella Sanders just simultaneously earned two degrees from Georgia Tech â€“ a Ph.D. in industrial engineering and an MBA from the Scheller College of Business. This now makes four degrees from four different programs at Tech. In 2019::: she earned masterâ€™s degrees in operations research from our College of Engineering and in geographic information science and technology from the College of Design.

Isabella::: the daughter of a Cambodian refugee and the first woman in her family to earn a Ph.D.::: will now join the engineering faculty at The United States Military Academy at West Point. -- https://c.gatech.edu/33Cqw9O

column1:
Georgia Techâ€™s Kendeda Building is the greenest building on any college campus in America::: and today it becomes one of only 28 buildings in the world to be certified as a Living Building::: the most ambitious::: environmentally sound building achievement on the planet.

The buildingâ€™s solar panels generate more than double the electricity needed to power it::: and the extra is returned to the grid for adjacent buildings. The solar panels also help collect and treat 15 times more water than the building needs. All told::: this building creates more energy than it uses::: and the lessons weâ€™ve learned will shape not only future construction projects on Georgia Techâ€™s campus but all over the world as well. | https://c.gatech.edu/3eroQ88

column1: Using pieces from Mars Rover prototypes he had built::: Georgia Tech engineering student Mirza Samnani built medical assistance robots that were deployed in hospitals to deliver food and medicine to Covid-19 patients. We have processed more than 300:::000 Covid-19 tests::: and our on-campus vaccine clinic has seen thousands of students::: staff::: and faculty members. We are now able to make a vaccination available to anyone in the Georgia Tech community who wants to take it.

Together::: we have rallied to protect each other::: and weâ€™re so proud of what weâ€™ve been able to do to keep moving forward. | http://c.gatech.edu/Vaccines

column1:
Jean McDowell Ray came to Georgia Tech in 1960 as one of Techâ€™s first women to study chemical engineering. She couldnâ€™t study chemistry as sheâ€™d hoped because women were only allowed to choose majors that weren't available to them at other schools. After following the curriculum::: she filed for a change of major to chemistry using her initials::: D.J. McDowell::: and it was approved.
Having already taken the prerequisites::: Jeanâ€™s major change request was granted::: and she earned her degree in chemistry in 1965. The following year::: all academic departments at Tech were opened to women. Jean McDowell went on to work for Boeing developing materials for airplanes. #WomensHistoryMonth
column3: And women are still fighting to control our destinies.

At Georgia Tech's Indoor Flight Laboratory::: researchers have developed an algorithm that allows a fleet of small drones to collaborate and lift heavy packages. The algorithm measures thrust and monitors altitude to estimate the weight of a package and can employ as many drones as needed to lift and complete a delivery.

In the future::: the system may be able to extend beyond commercial shipping and be used to resupply groups or soldiers in remote areas. | http://c.gatech.edu/DroneTeamDelivery

column1: To help as many local students as possible earn a Georgia Tech degree::: beginning this spring any first-year applicant not admitted will have a guaranteed transfer offer via the newly launched APS Pathway Program. The program will guarantee a spot for any Atlanta Public School student to transfer to Tech after completing 30 hours of credits in their intended major while maintaining a 3.3 GPA. -- http://c.gatech.edu/APSPathways
column3:
This is excellent. It is a matter of national security that we get more students of color graduated with STEM degrees. I remember when I went to Agnes Scott in the late 70's::: I only saw 2-4 African American students at Georgia Tech. There were very few women as well. This is a way to offset the soclai/
economic preferences that while-male student have had for sooo many years. This is a way to give poorer male and female underrepresente
d students a chance to be engineers.
column4: What a great program. Love to see the tie in with local public schools. You build the community that you live in.
column5: Everyone on here who is mad is missing the point. These programs start small and expand as they thrive and prove worth it. The fact that this is even starting should be applauded and supported.
column6: Why just APS? There are school systems all over the state::: with students who did not exactly excel in high school::: who arguably could use a second chance?
column7: This is not right. What about rural communities? Donâ€™t they deserve a spot as well?
column8: This is ridiculous unless you open it up to all students.
column9:
Inequality before the law was often an old norm in America. There are many who intend to make it a new norm.

Still::: sometimes the simplest explanation is the best-\-\-one very good explanation for the explicit favoritism of one geographic area was that this was lobbying by those who work at Georgia Tech to make sure their kids can one day get in. And that the administration had no moral courage to oppose. They could care less about the kid for Newnan::: nor Savannah::: nor Augusta::: nor Albany. It's about their kid having hope::: after all "that sacrifice" the parent did for the school.

This program will hopefully expand to other areas of the state (just as the valedictorian program did)::: as GT decides to every so often treat all equally under the law...despite itself. Still::: the fact is not everyone can get in or transfer in::: and given how long GT fought against other engineering schools being started in the state::: it to me is once more proof that it really doesn't think it is owned by the people of the state of Georgia::: but just by those who work there. I often think it has zero sense of what the word "stewardship on behalf of all Georgians" means. Nor cares.
column10: Itâ€™s so hard to stay at Tech that I feel like this is setting up students for failure. The problem is not getting in::: the challenge is staying and actually graduating. Itâ€™s not as easy as it seems
column11:
This just makes it that much harder for out of state students to be accepted at Tech....and it's already disproportionat
ely much more difficult as it is.

column1:
In a new space on campus::: Georgia Tech will be recognizing the painful past of segregation and the courage of those who sought to end it.

Our new EcoCommons includes the former site of the Pickrick Restaurant::: which was located off campus in the 1960s. The Pickrick closed to avoid a federal mandate to serve Black customers. When the EcoCommons opens later this year::: it will feature a display that honors the men who were assaulted when trying to enter the restaurant â€“ as well as space for contemplation and reflection for our entire community. | http://c.gatech.edu/TheJourneyContinues

Regardless::: it would be nice to at least commemorate this otherwise unknown gentleman with a plaque.

column1: Researchers at Georgia Tech are studying the collective behaviors of California blackworm blobs and applying those principles to robotics. Resembling an alien life form::: the blob allows the worms to survive longer and escape temperature threats while dividing responsibilities of movement. The research could lead to improved energy efficiency for swarm robots. | http://c.gatech.edu/WormBlobs

Erin and Andrew met during their first year at Georgia Tech and became friends cheering on the Yellow Jackets at Bobby Dodd together. They earned their degrees at the same time::: Erin in industrial engineering and Andrew in business. This evening::: Erin and Andrew were married at the Georgian Terrace Hotel just steps away from campus â€“ and they rode off in white and gold style. ğŸ’›ğŸ

column3:
Jason and I met in the stands at Bobby Dodd in November::: 1993. We were in the Chorale::: there to sing the alma mater at halftime. We were dating by the new year and have been together since. We're both BS Mgmt '97::: married six months after graduation::: and Jason returned for his MS MOT in '06.

That Alumni Association Wreck has seen a lot of weddings! ğŸ’•
column4: Met my wife when we were freshmen in 1974. In addition to her being one of only 2 women in our Aerospace Engineering class::: she was the waitress at the old Pippins Pizza on North Ave. we didnâ€™t start dating till we were Juniors and both graduated in 78. We both worked for General Dynamics /Lockheed for 40 years and have been married for 41
column5: Graduated BCE 87 and MSCE 89. Started working for a federal agency in 89::: but the job moved me back to campus in 91. My colleagues were teaching a class in spring 92::: and I decided to help out with the lab. At the end of the quarter::: I went on a lunch date with one of the students. We started dating::: she got an MCP in 93::: and we married in 95. This fall we dropped off our daughter at Tech for her first semester.
column6:
Married 47 years and GT has been a backdrop for it all. My husband was beginning his junior year in Architecture in â€˜72 when he took me to dinner in Atlanta and then a late night adventure to Grant Field. He wanted to show me the view. We walked up the ramps to the very top south corner of the west stands and it was magical! (Donâ€™t know if we were really allowed to be there::: but no one stopped us. ğŸ˜) Beautiful::: romantic view of the twinkling skyline! He surprised me with a proposal in that magical spot. I said yes! and we married a year later. I got a job in the GT library working at the Reserve Desk::: he began his Senior year::: and we moved into married student housing in the Healy high-rise just off 10th St (gone now) in a south-facing apartment with a million dollar view of the city and campus. He went on to receive his masters in Arch::: we have a son who graduated from GT::: and we love every opportunity we have to be on campus - feels like home! We miss football - 2020 was our first year in a very long time to not get season tickets. We love Georgia Tech! Go Jackets!
Rich Cole
column7: Edward Robertson and I met on a tour with the Chorale in 1994::: became best friends and a year later started dating. We got our degrees in 1994 and 1995 and got married in 1996. (And yes::: we drove away in the Ramblin' Wreck.)

column1: In 1968 Augustine Esogbue became the worldâ€™s first Black Ph.D. in the field of industrial engineering. Less than a decade later::: he became Georgia Techâ€™s first Black tenured professor and co-founded Georgia Techâ€™s chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers. Esogbue has mentored generations of scholars and his influence helped change the landscape of engineering in America by developing successful programs designed to cultivate and nurture minority success in STEM fields -- http://c.gatech.edu/3pTRZNS
column3:
Congratulations

Dr Esogbue for the many years you served as campus advisor for GT SBE.

This Black History post incorrectly states that Dr Esogbue was a
co-founder of GT chapter of NSBE. Following the lead of Black engineering students at Purdue University in 1975::: Black undergraduate students at Tech organized the GT chapter of Society of Black Engineers with GT Admin Dean of Engineering::: William "Bill" Schutz. The Dean appointed Dr Esogbue as the first advisor for this campus organization.

The chartering of GT chapter of NSBE was all student based. I was a Charter Member of GT chapter of SBE in 1976.

Its important that we are accurate with the history about the Black Experience at Tech.

Thanks:::
Francine McCarley
Freshman Class 1975
B.I.E. 1979

column1:
Georgia Tech Professor Russell Dupuis has received the 2021 Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering::: one of the worldâ€™s most prestigious awards. Dupuis is honored for his work in the creation and development of LED lighting technology that has totally changed how we illuminate the world. The science behind solid-state LED lights is used in sports stadiums::: commercial buildings::: and computer screens as well as cell phones::: automobile headlights::: and lightbulbs we use in the home. Dupuis and four of his colleagues led the initial development and commercialization of LED technologies that have contributed to reducing both global carbon dioxide emissions and energy demand.

column1: As Covid-19 vaccines arrive in communities around the country::: Georgia Tech biomedical engineers who work with the components of the vaccine are helping to explain how it is made and what makes it safe. The vaccines are made of two primary ingredients: a piece of mRNA and a lipid nanoparticle made from different fats. The mRNA is essentially a set of instructions â€” that tell our own cells how to kickstart an immune response against Covid-19. Because our body would not react well to just plain mRNA::: the lipid nanoparticle carries the instructions to the cells. -- http://c.gatech.edu/2LKggY4

â€œThe strength of any community is revealed in times of crisis and this year::: 2020::: has tested our community and it has revealed the best in us.â€

A message of gratitude from President Cabreraâ€™s front porch.

Two men have worked tirelessly to keep Georgia Tech's on-campus Covid-19 testing program running. Dale Allgood and Alfred Blue::: two custodial staff members::: volunteered to take on extra duties and help deliver the custom-made testing kits being used around campus. They also pick up the completed kits to be tested in our on-campus laboratory. Allgood and Blue spend hours each day driving around campus distributing and collecting the samples that have helped us keep our campus community safe throughout the pandemic. We thank these men and all the folks in our community who've helped keep up this incredible testing program. -- c.gatech.edu/38PyznE

During World War II::: every pilot had a code name.
When Floyd Blair flew 100 missions::: including over Normandy::: his code name was â€œRamblinâ€™ Wreck.â€ Floyd earned a French Legion of Honor Medal and a Distinguished Flying Cross. After completing his final tour of duty::: he went on to work as an electrical engineer::: having a long career as an advisor and consultant â€” and retiring at the age of 95.

This brave veteran and Georgia Tech graduate is celebrating 100 years this weekend. And although he canâ€™t have a party because of Covid-19::: his family and friends are collecting birthday wishes across social media platforms. -- https://c.gatech.edu/3kl1Okg

column6: One morning in 1971::: I woke at 0820 and panicked. I was late for English. It was the day before Thanksgiving::: and we only got three cuts::: and I was planning on taking my cut on Friday::: to be home in Knoxville::: TN::: for the long weekend. So::: I threw on a shirt and jeans::: and headed up the hill as fast as I could go. When I arrived at the classroom::: around 0830::: I discovered that most of the chairs in the room were empty::: and the prof (who I liked::: a lot) greeted me with a chuckle and asked::: "running late?" I apologized::: took my seat::: opened my 3-ring binder to take notes::: and saw my class schedule::: where it was plainly marked that my English class began at 0900. Oops. I'd had English at 0800 every previous quarter::: and this particular prof had a section at both 0800 and 0900 in the same classrom. So::: when she dismissed the class after the whistle blew::: she went to change her attendance record in her notebook::: looked at me::: and asked::: "What are YOU doing here?" I es'plained the mistake::: and the prof noted that she was flattered at my effort::: and told me::: "You don't have to stay. I hope the rest of your weekend goes better." So::: I walked over to the student center::: had bacon::: eggs and grits for breakfast::: and that was the last time I was ever 30 minutes early for a class at Georgia Tech.

135 years later::: we remain committed to the ideals of progress and service. We remain one of the nation's top public universities and the country's largest producer of engineers.

When students::: faculty::: and staff returned to Georgia Tech a few weeks ago for the start of the semester::: over 800 gold and white hearts dangled from trees across campus. Printed on every heart were words of encouragement::: warm memories::: and inspirational messages from the Yellow Jacket community.

The submissions were collected by a new student group dedicated to Spreading Messages in Love and Encouragement or SMILE at Georgia Tech. Each heart is meant to represent an individual's heart for the Georgia Tech community.

Georgia Tech::: once again::: has been ranked one of the nation's top public schools. According to U.S. News & World Report's 2021 rankings::: all of our engineering programs rank in the top five nationally::: with our civil engineering and industrial and systems engineering programs being ranked No. 1 in those disciplines overall.

Georgia Tech was also named the nationâ€™s top school for cybersecurity in the first-ever U.S. News rankings for computer science.

Programs from Georgia Techâ€™s Scheller College of Business also received U.S. News recognition::: with management information systems::: business analytics::: and quantitative analysis all ranked in the top five as well.

Additionally::: Tech came in at No. 3 on the best co-op and internship programs list::: was named the fourth most innovative school in America::: and was cited as one of the country's best schools for veterans. -- https://c.gatech.edu/32qsElo

column1:
Georgia Tech architecture graduate Michael Arad was two years out of grad school when he found himself running toward the World Trade Center towers on September 11::: 2001::: hoping to help amid the chaos. It was Arad's design of two 30-ft. deep reflecting pools sitting in the footprints of the fallen towers that was selected for the National September 11 Memorial in New York City. As part of his design::: Arad included the names of all who perished::: using computer software to create meaningful adjacencies to have relatives::: friends::: and co-workers placed on the memorial next to one another. #NeverForget

Read more: https://c.gatech.edu/3k6XDcc

column1: A message from President Ãngel Cabrera regarding Covid-19 testing and our campus community.

In the 1940s::: Georgia Tech students took in a speckled terrier after she was thrown from a car window in Atlanta. After several surgeries::: her head and tail werenâ€™t quite aligned and she walked with a limp::: hence her name: Sideways.

She attended classes::: ate table scraps at Brittain Dining Hall::: and even led our ROTC and football team onto the field at Bobby Dodd Stadium. She died in 1947 and is buried near Tech Tower.
Sideways' original straight headstone was replaced by a slanted one to remember her forever as she was. To this day::: Yellow Jackets leave a penny for Sideways at her grave::: hoping for a little luck on exams and the new school year. #NationalDogDay

Georgia Tech has developed a new way to test for Covid-19::: using saliva â€” no invasive nasal swabs required.
We're using this new method to screen for potential cases in our own community::: and testing all of the samples in labs on campus.

This approach will allow regular sampling of the Georgia Tech community::: with the goals of identifying silent carriers before they have the opportunity to transmit the coronavirus::: and helping them find medical support early.

Georgia Tech is using rapid notification via smartphone technology to slow the spread of the coronavirus from asymptomatic carriers and facilitate early Covid-19 testing on campus. -- https://c.gatech.edu/3haBCrM

column14:
I have a few unanswered questions::: which I would appreciate being answered as would many:

Will you be providing students with a choice as to whether or not we have to attend classes in person? Currently we are being told we have to attend our in person sessions for hybrid courses despite all classes being required to deliver both in person and online modes to provide access to all students. If students are not comfortable with returning to campus::: which is in a COVID-19 hotspot::: we should not have to. How do you plan to address and resolve this issue?

Also on the note of personal hygiene::: which is mentioned in your video::: how do you plan to combat the high population of students on campus that do not wash their hands after using the bathroom? Iâ€™ve witnessed it not only in my community style housing as a first year::: but out in public::: student-shared spaces. Does this not pose a large issue not only in relation to COVID-19::: but also on general student health?

Also::: how do you plan to keep campus reasonably quarantined? Students consistently go off campus during the week and on weekends to find fun things to do. Does this not pose a threat to maintaining a safe COVID free environment for students? Even if they wear a mask::: do not forget that COVID lives on surfaces and can be transferred by touching things. How do you plan to address student outings into Atlanta and surrounding areas? How do you plan to address large gatherings?

column1: As we prepare for a new semester::: things are looking different. We know that it's not going to be business as usual at Georgia Tech::: or anywhere else. That means #JacketsProtectJackets::: and we all have a role to play. -- http://health.gatech.edu/coronavirus/jackets-protect-jackets

Weâ€™ve acquired more than 106:::000 face coverings for campus and weâ€™ll be giving to two reusable face coverings to every member of our community on campus this Fall. There's not a city in the U.S. that doesn't have similar aging pipes and underground infrastructure.
The problem (as it was explained to me) is that the city has no clear idea where much of it is. Records have been lost or misplaced over many decades::: property lines have been redrawn::: and new stuff has been built on top of the old stuff.

And so everyone adopts a policy of "use it until it breaks"::: and then move in to aggressively repair and replace it.

This has more to do with legal issues than actual health. Studies have shown all-day mask wearing is inefficeient for preventing disease spread. Part of that is because people do not wear the masks properly or reach under them to scratch or have to take them off to drink::: eat::: spit gum out::: etc and still transfer germs only now they are inside not outside the mask and being continually held in contact with your respiratory system. Combining social distancing::: hand washing::: limited exposure inside with groups has been shown to limit or slow down the spread::: not prevent it. The type of mask also makes a difference::: but again::: most people do not properly wear masks and are lulled into thinking they do not have to social distance or sanitize their hands after touching any surface before touching their face or rubbing their eyes.
To be fair::: online classes should be offered to those who are imuno-compromis
ed. This works for math and English classes::: not so much for mechanics and lab classes though. Students::: staff and faculty are still being placed at risk and experimenting with masks when studies clearly indicate they are not longterm protection against disease spread is not the smartest choice to make.

column1: Strategically slow and energy efficient::: SlothBot uses solar panels to remain powered while collecting ecological data from the tree canopy for long periods of time. Georgia Tech roboticists partnered with conservationists from the Atlanta Botanical Garden to deploy SlothBot in the 30-acre Midtown Atlanta forest monitoring temperature::: weather::: carbon dioxide levels::: and other information from a single 100-foot cable. | https://c.gatech.edu/SlothBot

These two Georgia Tech undergrads have been using 3D printers at home to make face shields::: no-touch door openers::: and mask comfort devices for their first-responder family members. Now they are helping hospitals in communities across Alabama and Florida as well. -- https://c.gatech.edu/2Y8G5Eu

column1: Today::: weâ€™re sharing our plan to safely return to campus this fall. The plan includes changes to the calendar and course delivery::: strengthened health and safety protocols::: and a set of personal hygiene practices for all of us. Our goal is to bring our campus community back together and move forward safely::: responsibly::: and compassionately in pursuit of our important educational and research work while prioritizing everyoneâ€™s health and safety. Key among the many preventive measures will be a commitment by each one of us to maintain a safe physical distance from one another and to use facial coverings whenever distancing may not be feasible. And for students::: faculty::: and staff who might be at higher risk of contracting Covid-19::: we will establish alternative arrangements. The information on the link below will give you an overview of what our return to campus will look like::: what changes to expect::: what precautions we will take to keep our community safe::: and what you will need to do to help everyone enjoy a healthy and productive semester. Please note that there are still details to be worked out and some of our current protocols are subject to change as more information becomes available over the coming weeks. Our commitment is to share any additions and changes as soon as possible. Full plan: http://health.gatech.edu/tech-moving-forward

column1: In 2016::: Atlanta native and computational media major Kelsey Johnson lost her right leg to amputation. At the age of eight::: she'd been diagnosed with linear scleroderma::: a rare autoimmune disease that causes an overproduction of collagen. In June 2017::: Johnson took her first steps on a new prosthetic leg. Returning to Tech::: she vowed to treasure every moment and opportunity that followed. Today::: she is a Georgia Tech graduate and will achieve her dream of moving to New York City::: where she will start as a software engineer for American Express. | https://c.gatech.edu/2AamQkQ

column1: The malaria drug hydroxychloroquine has been promoted by some as a possible treatment for Covid-19::: but is known to have potentially serious effects on heart rhythms. Now::: a team of Georgia Tech researchers has used optical mapping technology to observe exactly how the drug creates serious disturbances in the electrical signals that govern heartbeat. -- https://c.gatech.edu/2Y6nQOM

We remember and honor Georgia Tech police officer James Cornacchia who lost his battle with Covid-19. Officer Cornacchia served the Tech community for nearly 20 years.

Georgia Tech Police Department
June 4::: 2020 at 2:08 PM Â·

On June 1::: 2020::: Officer James Cornacchia of the Georgia Tech Police Department (GTPD) lost his battle with Covid-19. He served the Georgia Tech community for nearly 20 years and most recently worked as part of our patrol unit. He was a loving father::: husband::: brother::: son and friend. Officer Cornacchia was a valued member of the Georgia Tech community and will be sorely missed.

During this difficult time::: we ask that you keep his family and friends in your thoughts and prayers. Please take some time to learn more about Officer James Cornacchia https://gf.me/u/x649v5

Officer Cornacchia was last on campus May 12::: and he did not develop symptoms within 48 hours of that day. Out of an abundance of caution::: all GTPD officers have been tested for Covid-19. Each of those tests came back negative. Georgia Tech continues to strictly follow guidance from the Georgia Department of Public Health and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Information for the Georgia Tech community related to the coronavirus outbreak::: including health and well-being guidelines::: can be found at health.gatech.edu."

column4:
As a GT alum::: I'm disappointed by the lack of actual substance in this response from President Cabrera. A lukewarm statement that you stand in solidarity with the Black community (of the university that you are the voice for) is less than the minimum effort you could make.

The student body is currently over 50% minority. How are their tuition dollars going towards protecting them from police brutality and fighting systemic racism?

How much is GT planning to donate towards causes fighting for racial justice? What steps are you taking to help students healing from trauma? Please respond with actions you are taking::: not a note of thoughts and prayers.
column5: Silence from President Cabrera is Violence
column6:
As a GT alum::: Iâ€™m embarrassed by this vague::: milquetoast statement. It has a strong â€œthoughts and prayersâ€ energy in part because it doesnâ€™t specifically mention any individuals::: teams::: or even defined plans being put in place as a response to the murders youâ€™re ostensibly addressing.

At one point::: President Cabrera::: you literally say â€œ...we demand change from those with the power to enact it...â€ Thatâ€™s you. You have the power. And yet you follow that statement by making absolutely no mention of GTâ€™s relationship with APD. This is not an opportunity for you to get some press about some ill-defined inclusion initiatives you kicked off a few months ago. You started your statement talking about George and Breonna and Ahmaud. Why do none of the solutions you offer have anything to do with the police?

What IS GTâ€™s relationship with APD? How much of the money your Black students pay in tuition each year gets funneled into an institution thatâ€™s proven lethal to Black bodies?

Also::: how dare you use students that youâ€™re educating to â€œthink critically about the society we live inâ€ in order to â€œlead us to a better placeâ€ as an example of your response to this moment? You are the president. You are the adult. How could you even consider shifting responsibility to teenagers?

Where is this â€œleadershipâ€ you keep talking about::: President Cabrera? I donâ€™t see it. Do better.
column7:
As a Georgia Tech alumni::: I will say that standing in solidarity is not enough.

When I went to Georgia Tech::: the ratio was 2 men to 1 woman and "underrepresent
ed minorities" (no distinction of race) was under 15% of the entire student body.

The brilliant Black students at Georgia Tech have the lowest acceptance rates and lowest graduation rates. Keep in mind::: Atlanta is a majority Black & African American city. Let me be clear::: this is NOT for lack of genius.

As one of the most affordable::: highest ROI public universities out there::: I will ask you again Georgia Institute of Technology::: WHAT are you DOING to support Black lives?

The data says that it is not enough.

column1: Today we honor and remember the Yellow Jackets and all Americans who paid the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom.

They weren't able to hold their Spring concert and were just plain missing getting together to sing in person. So Georgia Tech's all-male a capella group::: Sympathetic Vibrations::: decided they'd connect remotely to lay down some social distance-approved vibes.

During finals week at Georgia Tech his junior year in 2017::: Alex Syriopoulos lost consciousness at his apartment and had to be rushed to the hospital where he underwent life-saving brain surgery. He woke up from a coma::: paralyzed and unable to speak. After three years of therapy and re-learning to speak and walk::: Alex returned to Georgia Tech to complete his industrial engineering degree this semester.

â€œI am proud to be a part of this amazing community and wouldn't change my story in the slightest detail. Neither should you:::" he says. "Embrace your story." -- https://c.gatech.edu/2AUzy7d

column1: At over 750 degrees Fahrenheit::: it's hard to believe that the planet closest to the sun::: Mercury::: has permanent patches of ice. column1: In 1995::: recent Georgia Tech graduate Praise Shimosha was born in a refugee camp in Zambia. The year before::: his parents had fled war-torn Rwanda. They came to the U.S. when he was a child::: along with his five brothers and sisters. Today::: he and four of his siblings have earned bachelorâ€™s degrees::: with his youngest brother currently working on a degree in psychology. Praise just graduated with a B.S. in mechanical engineering and plans to pursue a master's degree here at Tech. -- http://c.gatech.edu/2LCnf1c

column1: Georgia Tech engineers have been working with NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration to make sure robots exploring other planets can avoid getting stuck like the Spirit rover that caught on Mars a decade ago. This planetary rover concept was 3D printed on Tech's campus has a special way to avoid getting stuck in sandy terrains. It can lift and wiggle its legs and wheels to get out of a tricky situation::: and engineers tested it in a giant vat of poppy seeds. -- https://c.gatech.edu/3cEzRRw

We've got some mighty mascots at Georgia Tech.
Armando Gonzalez portrayed Buzz for three years::: and just earned his degree in computer science. He's now working for Disney as a software engineer. Aaron Burtz wore the suit for two years before graduating with honors in mechanical engineering. He researched pediatric life support equipment as an undergrad and is now preparing to launch a startup company this summer. -- https://c.gatech.edu/3fU609C

column1: Kentez Craig grew up right here in Atlanta with both parents working as paramedics for local hospitals. Now::: as a master's student in engineering at Georgia Tech::: he is inspired by them as he helps develop and build protective equipment for first responders on the front lines fighting the battle against COVID-19. -- https://c.gatech.edu/2WWOLfd

Georgia Tech::: together with Emory University and Children's Healthcare of Atlanta::: are stepping up nationally to rapidly assess and calibrate new COVID-19 testing technology as part of a new federal initiative started by the National Institutes of Health. Together::: our researchers and healthcare experts will conduct clinical trials and help develop the manufacturing process::: and their goal is to make millions of accurate and easy-to-use tests available to Americans by the end of this summer. -- https://c.gatech.edu/2YYkOhp

column1: A team of students and researchers at Georgia Tech has built a prototype of a low-cost emergency ventilator to address acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)::: a common complication for COVID-19 patients. This device uses electronic sensors and computer controls to moderate respiration rate and lung pressure and aims to make breathing more natural by allowing patients to trigger their own breaths instead of relying on manual settings in the respirator itself. -- https://c.gatech.edu/2L2aUmR

Researcher::: Stamps President's Scholar::: Students For One Health Founder::: Animal Health Hackathon Champion (twice)::: Assistant Veterinary Tech::: Equestrian Team Rider::: Chorale Singer::: Ballroom Dancer::: Co-Founded AutoMattLLC::: created a stellar veterinary product::: filed a utility patent::: traveled the globe::: fed the homeless::: walked in the Rose Parade and took care of and rescued animals. Love:::
Mom and Gilad

column1: Georgia Tech's chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers has won the 2019-20 Large Chapter of the Year Award. These students coordinate innovative and inclusive events for Tech and the greater Atlanta community. (Photo taken earlier this semester.)

column16: This is a wonderful sea change from my days there (1959-1970). At that time the campus was poisonously conservative::: and they had very few women. The physics department would not accept women graduate students::: and the fraternities published a racist underground paper called the Techlique. I know of one fraternity that hosted a "Pig Party". They went to poor parts of town and invited women to a fraternity party. They gathered in a parking lot and had staged a bandstand with a group that they called the "Orange Orgasms". In the middle of the party::: on a signal::: they all disappeared::: leaving the women stranded. I know this because I went to High School with one of the organizers. My Alma Mater has come a long way. Unfortunately::: the undercurrents of bigotry and racism are still in the background.
